@saguziel do you have any ballpark data on how much this speeds up the scheduler?
@yk5, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @N3da and @jiwang576 to be potential reviewers.

Hi guys,

I see a lot of hard work and I understand what you are trying to accomplish. However, I do think you are trying to tackle too many things in one PR making it too big. In addition I would like to see a better design description. The commit and PR message do not describe why and what with reasoning. This makes it very hard to review.

Overall I think this PR needs to be split. I suggest splitting it into:

* Add max_tries and attempt to task instances
(Question: is max_tries related to attempts or retries? Please make sure you name correctly and update documentation)

* Move logging handling for TIs into logging.py
Here I would suggest to have something like

```
import airflow.logging as logging

log = logging.get_task_logger(task_instance)

```
`get_task_logger` should expose the standard logging interface.

* Obtain log per attempt per task instance in UI
`log.get_task_log(task_instance)`

airflow.logging is an interface to the underlying Handlers.


This makes it more manageable and allows for tracking down issues/regressions per commit.

@bolkedebruin I agree current logging mechanism is not ideal. Users should be able to setup their log handlers and not necessarily use the file handler. Let's discuss using log handlers more next week. I can work on it too.

By false positives I meant more like the new errors it gives for the new code are not correct. Code quality will not say coverage decreased if you just move around code (it will say that you have X new errors in the new code and highlight them, but it will also say X errors were fixed from the old removed code).

I agree with Bolke, but refactoring can be quite hard and I don't think the win in commit granularity has huge value, if you think it won't be super hard to refactor this into 3 PRs then I would encourage it (let's say less than an hour of work), otherwise I think it's OK to leave it. Also I think there might be some coupling between the parts that Bolke outlined (e.g. logging has to be changed if we break logs up by attempt # anyways).

Let's also make sure to add the note about the lock required for DB migrations and the addition of dag parsing to DB migrations, and the non-backwards compatible log locations to the commit message as these are big changes.
lgtm

@ronfung Great this is going to be included in Airflow!

I'm trying to move airflow log files to a Windows FileShare. Mounting it as CIFS in Linux. The problem is [that **:**  char is a reserved keyword.](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-gb/library/windows/desktop/aa365247(v=vs.85).aspx). All the DAG runs have a time with this char in it. With this addition we can mount it, replacing the _illegal_ char with something else.

_waiting for 1.9 to be released..._

**Edit:** I guess this is the file content format, not the filenames on disk...
